title: John Ward (footballer, born 1951)
text:
John Patrick Ward (born 7 April 1951) is an English <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and retired player.
A <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a> during his playing days, Ward appeared in <a href="the%20Football%20League">the Football League</a> for <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a>, <a href="Workington%20A.F.C.">Workington</a>, <a href="Watford%20F.C.">Watford</a> and <a href="Grimsby%20Town%20F.C.">Grimsby Town</a>, in which he scored 100 goals in 282 appearances. Having served under <a href="Graham%20Taylor">Graham Taylor</a> at Watford and <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> as assistant manager, he went on to manage <a href="York%20City%20F.C.">York City</a> and <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a> before being appointed as assistant at <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a>. Time in charge at <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a> followed and he then served as assistant at <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a>. Ward went on to manage at <a href="Cheltenham%20Town%20F.C.">Cheltenham Town</a>, <a href="Carlisle%20United%20F.C.">Carlisle United</a> and <a href="Colchester%20United%20F.C.">Colchester United</a> over a nine-year period before returning to Bristol Rovers, initially as manager before, briefly, becoming the club's <a href="Director%20of%20Football">Director of Football</a>.
Playing career.
As a player, Ward spent the bulk of his career as a forward at <a href="Lincoln%20City%20F.C.">Lincoln City</a> where he scored more than 100 goals between 1970 and 1979. He also had spells at <a href="Watford%20F.C.">Watford</a>, <a href="Grimsby%20Town%20F.C.">Grimsby Town</a> and <a href="Workington%20A.F.C.">Workington</a>.
Managerial career.
Following his retirement from playing, Ward was assistant manager to <a href="Graham%20Taylor%20%28football%20manager%29">Graham Taylor</a> at Watford from 1982 and then followed Taylor to <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a> in 1987. After Taylor became <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> manager in 1990, Ward remained at Villa for a further year and a half under <a href="Jozef%20Venglos">Jozef Venglos</a> and then <a href="Ron%20Atkinson">Ron Atkinson</a>.
York City.
In late 1991, Ward heard that <a href="York%20City%20F.C.">York City</a>, then a struggling fourth division club, had just sacked their manager. He happened to mention to his former boss Taylor in a phone call that he felt York would be a good club to start his own managerial career at, and Taylor in turn contacted the York City board (who had been considering appointing <a href="Billy%20McEwan%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201951%29">Billy McEwan</a> as manager) and recommended that they hire Ward, which they did. After his appointment, Ward turned York around and in the <a href="1992-93%20in%20English%20football">1992–93 season</a> and had them challenging for automatic promotion for much of the season. He left before the season ended, and promotion via the play-offs was achieved by his successor, <a href="Alan%20Little%20%28footballer%29">Alan Little</a>.
Bristol Rovers and City.
He later managed both <a href="Bristol">Bristol</a> clubs, <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a> and <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a>, and was assistant to <a href="Adrian%20Heath">Adrian Heath</a> at <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a>.
In 1998 Ward became assistant manager to <a href="Colin%20Lee">Colin Lee</a> at <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a>. After Lee's departure, he had a brief spell as <a href="caretaker%20manager">caretaker manager</a> before reverting to assistant under <a href="Dave%20Jones%20%28football%20manager%29">Dave Jones</a>. He helped the club win promotion to the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> in 2003 but left the club at the end of the season.
Cheltenham Town.
Ward was appointed <a href="Cheltenham%20Town%20F.C.">Cheltenham Town</a> manager in November 2003 and in 2006 guided the club to promotion into <a href="Football%20League%20One">League One</a>.
Carlisle United.
After keeping the Robins in League One the following season, he moved to <a href="Carlisle%20United%20F.C.">Carlisle United</a> in October 2007. Ward guided the club to a play-off position in his first season in charge, despite this however, a poor start to the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20in%20English%20football">2008–09</a> campaign saw him under heavy pressure to resign. He was later given the backing of the Carlisle board. However, he eventually parted company with the club by mutual consent on 3 November.
Ward applied for the vacant <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> managerial role in November after <a href="Maurice%20Malpas">Maurice Malpas</a> left the club by mutual consent. He held preliminary talks with <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a> over their managerial vacancy in May 2009, and was the favourite for the job, however lost out to <a href="Micky%20Adams">Micky Adams</a>.
Ward was then appointed as Stockport County's assistant manager after the appointment of Gary Ablett as Stockport boss.
Colchester United.
Ward became the assistant manager at <a href="Colchester%20United">Colchester United</a> in September 2009 when <a href="Aidy%20Boothroyd">Aidy Boothroyd</a> was appointed as the club's manager. Boothroyd resigned from his position in May 2010 to join <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a> which allowed Ward to take charge at the end of the month. Colchester finished tenth in their 2010–11 League One campaign and were tenth again at the end of the following season. He was sacked in September 2012 after the club began the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20in%20English%20football">new season</a> without a win in nine league and cup games, leaving them near the bottom of the table. "So much of Colchester United is better than it has ever been," said chairman <a href="Robbie%20Cowling">Robbie Cowling</a>, "but sadly that is not being reflected in first team results."
Second spell at Bristol Rovers.
Ward was appointed as manager of <a href="Bristol%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bristol Rovers</a> for a second time in December 2012. Having signed a contract until the end of the 2012–13 season, he succeeded <a href="Mark%20McGhee">Mark McGhee</a> to become the club's fourth manager in two years. Ward told <a href="BBC%20Radio%20Bristol">BBC Radio Bristol</a> that "I've got an affinity here that once I was asked to come and help I said yes."
His first match in charge was on 26 December 2012, a 2–2 draw against <a href="Aldershot%20Town%20F.C.">Aldershot Town</a>. Ward gained his first victory in charge in his second game winning 2–1 at home against local rivals <a href="Plymouth%20Argyle%20F.C.">Plymouth Argyle</a> (he had looked set and was actually en route to become Director of Football at Argyle before being appointed by Rovers). Having taken over with Rovers second from bottom and in the relegation places from the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a>, he achieved a 50% win ratio, with 42 points from 23 games, to guide them to a comfortable mid-table finish for the 2012–13 season.
His second season in charge proved more difficult as Rovers again struggled for form despite being among the pre-season favourites. On 28 March 2014, Ward was replaced as manager by his assistant <a href="Darrell%20Clarke">Darrell Clarke</a> and took up the role of <a href="Director%20of%20Football">Director of Football</a> at the club. Following the club's relegation out of the Football League for the first time since their election in 1920, Ward was sacked as Director of Football, just 41 days into the role.
